Where does the lending money come from Alan Paulos before these loans
Well the money used to come from essentially Wall Street because the ... it was private banks that were making these loans
Uh today this money comes from the federal treasury because as I said Obama um federalized all any program [noise] ah so the federal tax payer puts the money out a and the federal taxpayer 'em
And let's be clear we're not really talking about the taxpayers we're really talking about the department of education [noise] uh and it sort of crony contractors that's where the money is going and they they keep that
Essentially away from the taxpayer and they keep it for themselves [laughter] but um so yeah this was a federal program money it ultimately comes from the taxpayer who
At this point as I said is making something like Seventy five billion dollars a year in profit [noise]
Uh and even making a profit on ... I should add so that's a ... something that makes this a predatory lending system by definition
Are their predatory lending laws in the various states
There are there are state use three laws in every state in the union and federal student loans
Are exempted from all of them [laughter] there are also fair to collect the practice laws federal um a fruit
Than lending laws uh and these again are restricted or completely remove ah for the case of federal student loans

To a holy private for profit enterprise

Ah like many of the state run guaranteed horse in the country um like USA Funds
These people were all in it for themselves and they saw an opportunity to make money and they did everything they could to make these loans as oppressive as possible and here we are twenty Thirty years later living a under the the fruits of their labor
What do you recommend for a parent who use child is ready to graduate from high school and they want to go to college
Well the the only good advice that I can give at this point charge is do not borrow and if you have to borrow
Do not borrow from a student loan company so don't borrow federal student loans don't borrow private student loans from a bank you know that they were they were technically it is called a student loan
Because as soon as you call it a student loan federal or private you lose bankruptcy writes a and for federal loans you lose statute of limitations you lose fairly collection practices truth than lending a state use three laws all the all the rights all the consumer protections that I mentioned [noise]
Um so really don't borrow is the best advice I can have but if you actually have to borrow go to a private bank get any private line of credit and do it that way because at least then you'll have you know every consumer protection that exists for every other type of loan
Whatever happened to the days of scholarship so they still being awarded to people
Well you know George ... of course scholarships and grants are still out there but the colleges have been raising their prices so astonishingly much that you know no amount of ground serves even state funding has cetera
Can keep up with their budgets um you know I was just in Syracuse recently in the price to go to Syracuse University is now Seventy thousand dollars a year well I can
Guarantee you now you're per year that's tuition room board books um for for your course for a four year college and by the way it no longer takes for years to graduate George the average time to graduate from undergrad it's now six point two year what happened well again
The colleges are sitting in the ... seat vacant because there's this lending program standing behind the whole thing in the federal government and the other lenders are willing
To polish much dead on the back to the students as possible the colleges have carte blanche to not only raise their prices but also really stream the students out and keep them in college for as long as they can possibly do it [noise]
So it's it's the time is getting longer the per year cost is just exploding and that's why we're seeing these just insane stories where people are graduating with you know a million dollars in debt
... there was a story just recently where
